newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: NatMut aims to lift funds management profit.
newsitem.headline: NatMut aims to lift funds management profit.

text.p: Australia's National Mutual Funds Management (NMFM) said on Tuesday it expected higher profits in the year to September, partly due to some major new mandates to manage Japanese funds.

In the six months to June, it boosted its assets under management by almost A$1 billion, including A$230 million in Japanese funds to be invested in Australian and New Zealand debt, NMFM managing director Sam Kavourakis told reporters.
NMFM would earn a fee equal to between 45 and 50 basis points on those fixed-interest investment returns, he said.
"That's pretty good fee income," Kavourakis said. In Australia, the fee on fixed-interest ranges from 25 to 30 basis points, he added.
He was speaking after National Mutual Holdings Ltd reported an 18 percent surge in group interim profit to A$175.52 million for the half-year ended March 31.
NMFM contributed A$4.8 million in after-tax profit to the group result.
NMFM hopes to lift its gross profit margins to around 20 to 25 percent for the full-year ending September 30, from around 18 to 19 percent now, Kavourakis said.
"I think we can get pretty close to achieving that this year," he said.
At March 31, NMFM's total funds under management totalled A$25.3 billion, up from A$23.2 billion at September 30.
